metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Sub-Inspector of Police

facts.text: Respondent was a Sub-Inspector of Police in the State of Madhya Pradesh.
Departmental enquiry initiated against respondent by Superintendent of Police, Surguja on June 24, 1962 on basis of certain charges.

Superintendent of Police held enquiry as prescribed by Central Provinces and Berar Police Regulations and submitted report to Inspector-General of Police, Madhya Pradesh through Deputy Inspector-General of Police, Raipur.
Superintendent of Police concluded respondent guilty of charges and recommended dismissal.
Inspector General sent copy of report to respondent and called upon him to show cause why he should not be dismissed.
Respondent submitted explanation to show cause notice.
Inspector General of Police dismissed respondent from service on November 30, 1963 after considering explanation.
Respondent's appeal to Government against dismissal order rejected.
Respondent moved Madhya Pradesh High Court under Art. 226 for writ of certiorari to quash dismissal order in Misc. Petition No. 646 of 1964.

High Court by judgment dated November 4, 1965 rejected all grounds except one: held Superintendent of Police, Surguja not competent to initiate or conduct enquiry as he was appointed by Inspector-General; enquiry without authority of law and against Art. 311(1); allowed writ and quashed dismissal order.
Superintendent of Police initiated and conducted enquiry on basis of Regulations 228 and 229 of Central Provinces and Berar Police Regulations.
Superintendent of Police complied with requirements of Regulations 228 and 229.
Superintendent of Police, Surguja appointed by Inspector-General of Police.

legal_issues.text: Whether the power conferred on Superintendent of Police under Regulations 228 and 229 to initiate and conduct disciplinary enquiry is ultra vires Art. 311(1) of the Constitution, i.e., does Art. 311(1) require that the authority empowered to dismiss must alone initiate and conduct the disciplinary proceedings.
Scope of Art. 311(1): whether it implies authorities mentioned must initiate and conduct enquiry culminating in dismissal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Art. 311(1) does not in terms require the authority empowered to dismiss to initiate or conduct the enquiry preceding dismissal or even that enquiry be done at its instance; only guarantee is no dismissal by subordinate authority.

respondent_arguments.text: Power of dismissal and removal in Art. 311(1) implies authorities mentioned must alone initiate and conduct disciplinary proceeding culminating in dismissal; Superintendent not competent as appointed by IG.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred; Art. 311(1) only provides no dismissal by subordinate to appointing authority; does not require that authority to initiate/conduct enquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only right guaranteed is no dismissal by subordinate authority.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 310(1) pleasure doctrine subject to Arts. 309 and 311; Art. 309 allows rules on conditions of service including dismissal; Regulations 228/229 valid under Art. 309.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dismissal falls within conditions of service regulable under Art. 309.

court_reasoning.text: Conditions of service include provisions regulating dismissal, as per precedents.

holdings.text: Art. 311(1) does not require appointing/dismissing authority to initiate or conduct disciplinary enquiry; only prohibits dismissal by subordinate authority.
Power under Regulations 228 and 229 not ultra vires Art. 311(1).

precedents_cited.case_name: Pradyat Kumar Bose v. The Honble the Chief Justice of Calcutta High Court
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissal of official falls within conditions of service.

precedents_cited.case_name: North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand
precedents_cited.relevance: Right of dismissal is condition of service under s.243 Govt of India Act 1935.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. Balakotaiah v. The Union of India and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule for termination of service made under ss.241(2), 247, 263 Govt of India Act 1935.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 311(1) limits dismissal authority; Art. 309 enables rules on service conditions; Art. 310 pleasure subject to these.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces and Berar Police Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribe procedure for enquiry by District Superintendent; complied with.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for framing police regulations on recruitment and conditions of service.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court disagreed with High Court, held that Art. 311(1) does not require dismissing authority to conduct enquiry; enquiry by SP valid; impliedly quashed High Court order restoring dismissal.

key_quotes.text: Art. 311(1) provides that no person... shall be dismissed or removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines exact scope of Art. 311(1) guarantee.

key_quotes.text: The only right guaranteed to a civil servant under that provision is that he shall not be dismissed or removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The expression 'conditions of service' is an expression of wide import.
key_quotes.speaker: court
